description.narrative:
Education and jobs needed
the quality and relevance of the education received also requires attention. As in other Arab countries, the (higher) vocational education system is not well preparing youth for the labor market, let alone to become a successful entrepreneur. The Booking institute in recent research concludes that the lack of alignment between education and employment is a skills mismatch, whereby, according to industry experts, youth are not well equipped for the world of work today. Also the WANA Institute observes that a “mismatch between education and labour market needs and cultural stigma surrounding certain vocational and male-dominated professions”. The Jordanian National E-TVET Strategy 2014-2020 recognizes this shortfall as focuses one of the four pillars on improving the relevance for employability of the TVET education, bringing in the private sector as the driver of change. Interventions in this area are thus in the centre of national policy efforts.
At the same time, opportunities for Jordanian youth are also limited. Unemployment amongst Jordanians is highest among youth at an estimated 28.8 per cent, and for socio-economically marginalized families, higher education is unaffordable. As an estimated 1 in 10 residents in Jordan by now is a Syrian refugee, tensions between the communities exist and can escalate. A programme thus needs to be inclusive in serving both Jordanian and refugee youth at the same time, preferably in integrated activities. Another crucial element is to not only focus on the employability, but on creating new jobs through entrepreneurship.
